--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Umer Iqbal" <umeriqbal81@h...> wrote:
> 
> Regarding the fact that the net that evolved had 44 neurons:
> 
> There must be more than on solution to the given problem. And as I
myself have come across some solutions (to another problem posted
earlier) that are equally as good but vary in network complexity
(number of neurons and connections varied in order of tens), I must
say that 44 neurons might be just one possible solution. And that NEAT
might have missed a simpler solution earlier in the evolution process
due to some reason. 
> 
> Now, If my above statements are correct, then what could be the
possible reasons why NEAT missed the simpler solution/s? Was it
because that we complexified at a rate higher than we should have? or
was it just because of the nature of evolutionary process itself? or
was it due to some other reason? 
> and what can we do about it?
> 

I think in this experiment Mitchell did not use NEAT.  He just used a
standard fixed-sized fully-recurrent network.  I think that's why he
uploaded the code for this experiment- so that someone on this group
might attempt it with NEAT.  It would definitely be interesting to see
what NEAT would come up with.

ken
